content.description:
A four bolt extension to Fresh Cut. Big pulls on good holds leads to the lip where a hard boulder problem guards the chains.

Bolts

4 bolts of fun ascending great blue stone. You can tell one of the old boys spent alogn time cleaning this short approach pitch, respect that.

middle of lower wall
bolts

Solid for the grade! 35ms of technical wizardry. A mega classic and top 100 status for a reason. Starts with some fun but suspect rock. The wall starts to bulge off a good rest then its "mini boulder problem" game on. The slopper crux in the middle feels hard in mid summer, super chill during "unicorn" temps. 


Ascends the chossy pillar-like feature just right of the "Sea of Holes" sector (pocketed, short but steep section of the wall). Left of the bolt line with the chain draw at the bulge (Original Dogs). 


13 bolts, chains with biners

New rig from the mind of Mason. Climbs well and some corner work for those who like to slap. See picture

See photo
Bolts

Just right of Last Stop 305 Bus. Shares the start with Underestimated, 12c. Tread carefully through the 5.10 start to a no hands rest below the corner. Steep pumpy climbing leads to a crux near the top of the corner and some exposed slab moves to a fixed draw. From the fixed draw, head up and right for fun climbing on great rock. There is a 5.11 crux passing the last bolt...don't blow it!

17 Bolts - Clip-n-Go Anchor - Stick Clip the First Bolt

Climbs the overhanging prow right of Pandora, high above the "Sea of Holes" at Lower Acephale.

Climb either Badger Crack (5.7+) or Approach Route (11d) to Pandora, at the 7th bolt continue to trend right through easy climbing to a no hands rest at the base of the prow. Launch into steeper climbing strait up (avoiding the chossy corners to the right) to a fixed chain-draw. From the fixed draw to the chains its nothing but fun juggy climbing with excellent exposure, your primary job is keeping the pump at bay...Enjoy!

The right exit out the steep roof goes at 13d - Contraception.

16 Bolts - 32m - Clip-n-Go Anchors

THE PREEMINENT 12C OF THE BOW VALLEY!

(hyperbole aside, this pitch is fantastic!)

This is essentially a link up of The Dark Half and Last Dance with a bit of independent climbing. Begin on Dark Half following the tricky (not strenuous) 5.11 climbing for 6 bolts of fun.  At this point instead of heading Left up Dark Half, cut right and follow the diagonal crack system.  This section of independent climbing was very "trad-y" and memorable, underclings and smears are the name of the game. It was very reminiscent of granite trad climbing. When you arrive at the intersection with Last Dance get a good shake. The finish is pumpy and powerful.  Fortunately, the sequence is fairly easy to read with most of the holds being visible from below.  The final section of rock is flawless- a reminder that the rock gods have shown favor on Acephale.



Begins on The Dark Half (immediately Right of Nemo - which is easy to find cause "nemo" is written on the rock in paint pen)


11-12 bolts (extend the middle draw of the traverse or you might get a tad bit of unwanted rope drag while cruxing out on the finishing boulder problem.)

A very hard middle crux that doesn't really let up after that. One good shake and then gun it for the top on some good grey stone in an overhang. 

Start a a left leaning ramp with a small roof. 
about 15 bolts, should have Johnny's draws on it.

Testpiece for the grade.

High quality route with several tough Boulder problems separated by decent rests.  The final one being the most cryptic and difficult. Impeccable stone. 


Right of Naissance 

8 Bolts

The wandery middle line starts easy then straight away tackles a boulder problem over a large bulge. Fun tech climbing gets to a good rest, with another boulder problem lurking above. Great quality


Shared start with "Hickory Dickory Dock" up the massive marginal quality flake. Bolts 4 and 5 have perma's that trend left over a bulge. 


12 bolts, 3 permas, fixed anchor with biners

A new steep route on the upper Pandora headwall. Shares the first few bolts of the Badger Crack 5.7, before traversing left onto the face to a steep boulder problem. Tough cruxes separated by awesome rests above.

Bolts

One left of La Part Maudite. A hard to read crux may spit you off your onsight but this route will become a great warm up for the crag.

Bolts

A fantastic journey for 28ms. Starts with a nice 11- bottom half into a full no hands rest. The wall goes from vertical to very overhung bulges, where you will have to get your boulder on. The moves start to increase in difficulty and the clips get really awkward and hard with the final v5 boulder problem being quite friction dependent. Really is pure power endurance and maybe a 3 move 12+ crux, but man do you get tired on route out of no where.

Right side of The Junction.
bolts

Shares the first few bolts of the Badger Crack 5.7, before traversing left onto the face. Tough boulder at mid height might be challenging to shorter folks. Clipping the chains is entertaining to say the least.

Bolts

38ms long! Beaut boulder problem in the mid guts

At the Junction 
Bolts

Extremely hard for one draw and then onto the regular route of Ice Cream Head. A non-direct start is just to the left which bumps down the grade to 12d (may not be possible, no recent sends on sendage confirm if possible due to holds breaking off). 

Bolts

A right facing flake to a really hard crux and then some much easier climbing after this on a nice blue streak on the wall. 

Find the flake and next to Ice Cream Head (not direct). 
bolts

Slopers and underclings and weird climbing! Have fun trying to do this as a warm up. Once you get it should relent a bit

Bolts

Start on great pockets, through a technical 5.11 section to a ledge. A sustained boulder problem awaits above.

10 Bolts to a Clip-n-Go Anchor

Two very distinct cruxes with some restful climbing in between. Large run out to the chains make it for a fun outing. 

to the left of naissance
about 10 QDs

Start in an awkward but easy corner. move up and to a good rest after a small roof. Super vicious crux awaits to a good rest and another crux. Hold on until the end!

Last rout on this block of routes before the very obvious easy start of Nyctophobia 
about 10 bolts

Shares the 5.10 start with Nyctophobia, but goes right over the bulge. 

Bolts

Easier finish to Go Ask Alice. Start at the same spot as Alice and trend right when possible. Hard roof.

15 draws or so

Hard sloper finish, very technical with some interesting rests along the way. Quite vertical and crimpy


Left side of the wall, just before the trail starts to go down hill.


7 bolts (1 perma), chain anchor with biners

A bow valley classic. Some will debate endlessly if it is a 13a parading as a 12d. Probably due to the nature of how pumpy this thing is. 

Generally accepted as 4 hard cruxes with not much resting in between. 

The opening dihedral near the end of the cliff, hard start. Near where's mom. 
about 15 bolts

Follow left-trending features past several bulges to an anchor.

On the left side of the wall, just left of a yellow streak marking the start of Where's Mom 
5 bolts

Starts up a pocketed shield feature just right of an area of marginal rock. The first half of the low section is a bit pumpy, but eventually leads to jugs that trend left to a low set of anchors (Nitro Lite), skip these, as well as the last bolt, and head up and right to the ledge. 

From the ledge, clip a bolt on the easy slab, and another on the headwall. Perhaps make a move to clip the second bolt on the headwall, and reverse the move for a quick shake (and back clean your slab bolt). Have your belayer keep you tight as you pull a boulder on side-pulls and crimps that requires a bit of tension (edge fall potential). The boulder finishes with smashing another ledge, but you'll have to mantle before you're safe from the pump!

Victory climbing to the chains. 


right most route

12 bolts, chains with biners

Traverse from the left side of an obvious yellow streak, up and right through some pockets and sidepulls to a small ledge. Head up and back left across the stream to easier terrain.

Where the approach trail reaches the lower wall, under a yellow streak.
7 bolts to an anchor

Very easy climbing to a high off the deck bouler problem.

up the right wards ramp near last dance
10 bolts or so

Start up the right leaning badger crack to a ledge (5.7). Head up the face through 2 bolts of near vertical climbing to a sloping ledge - take the left branch here. Pull an uncomfortably thin and sharp boulder off the sloping ledge to gain the main ledge below the headwall.

Big moves on good holds (~12c) gets you to a rest below the last bolt on a big block. Your next hold is that flake way up and right. The standard thought process is "I will absolutely not dyno" until you touch the crimp option and settle on "okay, massive dyno it is." 

A few big moves on good holds take you to a clipping bucket above the anchor. 

Originally went at 5.12d with an artificial hold bolted on that let you skip the dyno. Chopped after the proper FFA.



Conception trends right, up the prow of the headwall and has a big chain draw you can see from the ground. This is the bolt line about 3 m to the left. Shared start on Badger Crack, the lines diverge a couple of bolts above the end of the crack. 


16 bolts, rap rings with biners. Extend most draws on approach and your first two on the headwall.

Smash absolute buckets up until the lip, pull up and right after the last bolt over the lip to the anchor (no buckets). 



Second bolt line from the left on Sea of Holes Wall - maybe the most obvious line of big pockets (think two hands, elbows deep buckets). 

6 bolts, fixed anchor with biners

Fun moves on sloping edges and pockets on great rock leads to a ledge halfway up the cliff.

5 bolts to a Clip-n-Go anchor

Technical slab climbing leads to a steeper section going to the top of the cliff

Bolts

climbs.name: SR 16
climbs.fa: Prep S. Steiner, FA Scott Milton

content.description:
Start up the left facing corner shared with The Dark Half and The Dark Dance. Don't worry, this won't ruin your on-sight for those climbs, you'll have to on-sight this corner every time you try it. From the rest above the initial corner, follow the overhanging right facing corner on big underclings and small feet to a good rest where the bolt line splits and veers onto the headwall (Dark Dance), ignore that option and continue up the final meter or two of the corner to a ledge. Just 4 bolts above the ledge. 

Hero boulder off the ledge to a rest jug that very quickly becomes a sloper. Pull out of the overhang to a rest below the slab. At this point...I guess you just clip the biner on the last bolt and start yanking your draws. No anchors - just a biner on each of the last to bolts. 



Look for the right leaning corner that cuts under a big block at mid-height on the wall (Dark Half). This is the corner you're aiming for, connect the bolt line to the ground. The exit is about plum with the first 6 bolts of The Last Dance. 

14 bolts, no anchor

Hard top crux

Bolts

Just right of Last Stop 305 Bus. Shares the start with Chawesome Corner, 12b. Tread carefully through the ratty 5.10 start to a no hands rest below the corner. Steep pumpy climbing leads to a crux near the top of the corner and some exposed slab moves to a fixed draw. At the 13th bolt, head left on the obvious bolt line into the steeper terrain. Steep juggy climbing takes you to the top of the wall, complete with a tufa pinch crux!

17 Bolts - Clip-n-Go Anchor - Stick Clip the first bolt

A good route worth doing. Interesting climbing to a strange pocket traverse and hard finish. Go get the jug!

left of the 'Nemo' Corner
~15 bolts

This is the first wall you hit on the approach at Acéphale. It is shaded and quite nice in the trees. The climbing tends towards slopey edges on good to fantastic rock. I thought I was in a virgin Ceuse on the route Deal With It over towards the left. The rock up high on the routes tends to be sharper. 
  
 Don't expect to be alone here as these are some of the harder routes with one of the shorter approaches in the Bow Valley.
